sect1.title: What is &Kernel;?
sect1.para: &Kernel; is a Unix-like kernel which is written by Linus Torvalds and other developers, who communicate using the internet. &Kernel; runs on many different architectures, for example on many IA32, IA64, Alpha, m68k, SPARC and PowerPC machines. The latest kernel and more information can be found at: http://www.kernel.org

&Kernel; is often confused with the &OS; system. &Kernel; is only a kernel, not a complete operating system. &OS; consists of the GNU operating system with the &Kernel; kernel. Please read the following section for a more detailed explanation of &OS;.

sect1.title: What is &OS;?
sect1.para: At the beginning of the eighties Richard Stallman started an ambitious project with the goal to write a free Unix-like operating system. The name of this system is GNU (GNU is Not Unix). At the beginning of the nineties most important components of the GNU oparating system were written, except for the kernel, which is still under development under the name HURD. HURD consists of some servers which provide Unix-like kernel functionality. In turn these servers run under the Mach microkernel. At the beginning at the nineties the HURD team still had to wait till the Mach sources were released as free software. In the meanwhile Linus started filling the gap with the &Kernel; kernel. &OS; thus refers to the GNU system running on the &Kernel; kernel. Right now the HURD kernel is also in a usable state and can be downloaded in the form of the GNU/HURD operating system. The Debian project has even developed a version of the GNU operating system which works with the NetBSD kernel. We should call &Kernel; distributions &OS; distributions, because GNU is a substantial part of most distributions.

sect1.title: What is &Distribution;?
sect1.para: &Distribution; is a &OS; distribution which is maintained and developed by Patrick Volkerding. In contrast to many other distributions &Distribution; adheres to the so-called KISS (keep it simple stupid) principle. This means that &Distribution; does not have complex graphical tools for configuring a system. For newbies this can be somwhat harsh, but it provides more transperancy and flexibility. Besides that you will get to learn &OS; to the bones with &Distribution;.

Another distinguishing aspect of &Distribution;, that also complies with the KISS principe is the &Distribution; package manager. &Distribution; does not have complex package manager like RPM. Packages are normal tgz (tar/gzip) files, mostly with an additional installation script and a package description. Tgz is much more powerful than RPM for novice users and avoids dependency problems. Another famous feature of &Distribution; are the BSD-like initialization scripts of &Distribution;. &Distribution; has one initialization script for each runlevel insteas of a script for eacht daemon. It allow you to tweak with your system easily, without the need to write net init scripts yourself.
The packages in &Distribution; are compiled with as little modifications as possible. This means you can use most general &OS; documentation.

listitem.para: &Kernel; 2.4.29 - &Distribution; uses the proven 2.4 Linux kernel as the default kernel. &Distribution; 10.1 provides &Kernel; 2.6.10 as an option. When a 2.6 kernel is booted, &Distribution; will automatically use udev, which is a daemon that automatically generates /dev device entries.
X11R6.8.1 - This is the second &Distribution; to provide the X Window System provided by the X.org Foundation.
GCC 3.3.4 - Version 3.3.4 of the GNU Compiler Collection is provided. GCC provides C, C++, Objective-C, Fortran-77, and Ada 95 compilers.

The K Desktop Environment (KDE) 3.3.2 - The full KDE environment is provided, which includes KOffice, the Konqueror web browser, multimedia programs, development tools, and many more useful applications.
The GNU Network Object Model Environment (GNOME) 2.6.1 - GNOME is a popular GTK2 based desktop environment.

sect1.title: &Distribution; on CD-ROM
